article: Patrick never did homework. "Too boring," he said. He played baseball and basketball and Nintendo _ . His teachers told him,"Patrick! Do your homework or you won't learn a thing." And it's true, sometimes he did feel like a ding-a-ling . But what could he do? He _ homework.  Then on St. Patrick's Day his cat was _ with a little doll and he grabbed it away. To his _ it wasn't a doll at all, but a man of the tiniest size with a high tall hat. He shouted, "Save me! Don't give me back to that cat. I will make any of your wishes come true. I _ you that." Patrick couldn't _ how lucky he was! Here was the answer to all of his problems. So he said, " Only if you do all my homework until the end of the semester. If you do a good enough job, I could even get A's."   And _ to his word, that little elf began to do Patrick's homework. The elf didn't _ know what to do and he needed help."Help me! Help me!" he'd say. And Patrick would _ to help--in whatever way. "I don't _ this word," the elf squeaked while reading Patrick's homework. "Get me a dictionary. No, what's even _ . Look up the word and sound it out by each letter." When it _ to math, Patrick was out of luck. "What are tables?" the elf squeaked. "We elves never need that. Here, sit down beside me. You simply must _ me." The little elf, already a shouter, just got louder , "Go to the library, I need books. More and more books. And you can help me read _ too."  In fact, every day and in every way that little elf was a nag ! Patrick was working harder than ever and was staying up at night. He had never felt so _ that he was going to school with his _ puffed and red. Finally the last day of school arrived and Patrick got his A's which _ his classmates, teachers and parents.
